reviewText:
A great game overall.

Build a maze and place defensive towers in the building phase. Then just click enter and start shooting the enemy creatures with your own guns.

That's a great mechanics and it didn't change since the first game. But there are some drastic changes which fans of the first Sanctum didn't enjoy: now the player is vulnerable to attacks, so mosters can kick your ♥♥♥ if your are a slowpoke. Moreover, some monsters are now aggressive and start chasing the player if he gets in range of their attack. Even more than that: blocks on top of which you place towers are now significantly lower than in the first game, so even if you are standing on top of a block, the monsters can still punch you right in the face! And one more thing: the number of blocks and towers that can be placed on a level is limited.
Compared to the first game, this one has different characters to play, lots of perks and a leveling system providing a great versatility for playing and making completing the game fun (both solo-mode and 2-4-player mode)
If you have played the first Sanctum, then you can already decide whether you want this game or not.
If you haven't... well just TRY IT! It's a lot of fun! :D

reviewText:
Sanctum 2 is a very robust game, it provides a lot of fun and challenge in equal measure.
The graphics are first-rate, the landscapes and scenery in the game world are breathtaking, Leonard Hummer's soundtrack is gorgeously composed, the game's characters are full of personality and have very nice designs, and the consistantly different levels means there's never a dull moment.

The level of customisation in the game is incredibly diverse, even without DLC weapons and 'Perks' (abilites that provide buffs and other useful effects in-game) - there are a lot of different loadouts one can equip. Difficulty level is also customisable, instead of a traditional 'Easy - Medium - Hard - etc.' setup, this game employs the 'Feats of Strength' system, allowing you to customise how hard to make the game, options to increase enemy health, speed, and strength are all seperate, giving you a more gradual difficulty slope as you get more confident.

Multiplayer is another fantastic part of this game, allowing you to create or join a server at the touch of a button. You can create a private server and invite your friends to it, or make a public one and fight alongside complete strangers, or browse the public server list and help other players.

As someone that's obtained every achievement for this game, I can say there is still plenty more this game has to offer, different loadouts to try, different tower combinations, different maze layouts, I now spend time on public servers, helping them to progress through the game and I'm always fascinated by all the new and interesting approaches to the levels that I'd never even considered in my playthrough.

Overall, very well polished, very enjoyable game with loads of content and replayability. I highly recommend Sanctum 2, you won't be disappointed with it.

reviewText:
Picked it up while it was on sale, best decision this week.

I bought this game so a friend and I would have a co-op shoot-em up that wasn't as simple as shooting, camping and getting mad at the screen. I also thought it was probably gonna be okay if I spent 4 dollars buying us both the game; it's not like I've wasted more money on a ♥♥♥♥♥ier game.. *cough*

So, turns out this game is pretty fun. Spent a solid 2 hours slaughtering aliens in campaign until we reached a point where we couldn't advance; but that was perfectly fine! Every defeat offered us a new idea, a new maze, a new strategy. We got to a point where we had everything proritized and every turret where it needed to be. The feeling is glorious. My friend, who frequents the sniper class, expressed how amazing it was to have me down the sight watching me blow aliens to chunks.

It's not the best game, but it's definitely worth a play through, and definitely worth buying on sale. 8.5/10

reviewText: Tower here, Tower there...\n\nSanctum 2 is a First-Person Tower Defense game that is amazing, and needs to be purchased and added to your library right away. The game is beautiful, I sometimes just run around taking screenshots its so pretty, I love the map designs and character designs especially. Multiplayer with someone you know is to be prefered, I personally can't enjoy a game when I'm lonely. The various towers and weapons given to you are fun and enjoyable to use, and every item has a purpose. Being a defender of the core, and building your own death maze to  murder  the invasive monsters, as your robot companion ask for coffee, is a very fun filled endeavor.  By far the best feature is the robot voice that speaks when you type to communicate to your team.  Combat has a sci-fi feel, and there is a very satisfying sound that emits from your rocket launcher as you squelch your enemies and are thrown by knockback. The easter eggs hidden in the game are a fun surprise to hunt for, and I loved the references I saw.  Overall, if you enjoy a strategic multiplayer game to play with your mates, pick up Sanctum 2 and place those tower bases.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about this game.

While the gameplay is incredible, the difficulty is too high to maintain in early stages. You often lack the basic resources to have a small chance at defeating the massive hordes of enemies. While this is not a initially bad thing, as it is a TD/FPS hybrid, it stays that way throughout the entire mission. Difficulty does not seem to scale with the lack of players you have.

The tutorial is one of the worst I have seen, giving very little information about how to play the game or what anything on screen means.

I can't say much about the story, as I haven't played the original.

The characters/weapons are okay at best. The only one I truly enjoyed playing was the sniper robot, because it is the most diverse. The Squad Leader character's weapon has too much recoil to be worth the shot (thank you, thank you, I'll be here all night).

TL;DRSanctum 2: Yet another reason we need a in-between review button.

reviewText: Sanctum 2 took the best parts of the Original and brought it to the next level, adding something of a story to the mix, expanding on the First person shooter aspect by allowing the player to traverse through the game world from one level to the next and involves the player more in the defense as opposed to just focusing on towers. Visually speaking, Sanctum 2 is crisper, cleaner and more up to date with graphics of newer games even though it was released in 2013. There were some changes to the tower building component as well as the use of personal weapons. In the original you built towers by spending resources, now you are given a number of towers to start with and can place them anywhere, with more towers given to you upon completion of each wave. This makes the challenge a little different as it may take a few waves to redirect the flow of enemies. The changes to personal weapons are that you now need to reload, as opposed to the auto-reload of the original. This makes it more realistic and presents challenge by forcing you to manage your ammunition.\n\nI thought Sanctum 2 took everything to the next level and was a great sequel from a pretty fun game. It has similar options to the first regarding single player or multiplayer, so if you enjoyed playing the original Sanctum you should really enjoy Sanctum 2.

reviewText:
The game is not as exact as the original, in design and gameplay - There are bugs and problems.

It is a cross-platform hybrid FPS/Tower Defence game with online matchmaking of various modes and styles, featuring a few customisable character classes and an abundance of weapons, towers and perks. Maps are often not limited to the tower grid and sometimes cover vast explorable distances. Enemies are varied in type and offer ideas for different tactics and strategies though somewhat limited in count. The last wave in a round frequently provides additional challenges and frustrations.

So the game offers an interesting blend of thoughtful tower defense and mindless shooting, all wrapped around cool explosions and a chance to deviate from regular gameplay.

reviewText:
What can I say about this game? I could discuss its tight controls and fun combat. I could talk about the beautiful art style or the ever expanding loadout configurations. We could even focus on some of the most kick-♥♥♥ DLC I've ever seen.

But that isn't what sold me this game. Instead, I want to explain the studio's personal touches.

First of all, all of the levels have hidden in-game items. This turns each level into a scavenger hunt which forces the player to take a tour of the enviroment and possibly uncover another hidden gem. Easter eggs/hidden rooms. This game is full of them! From functioning arcade machines to secret codes, this game is full of fun surprises. It adds character and humor to another masterpiece from Coffee Stain Studios.

reviewText:
Sanctum 1 was a great fusion of Tower defence and First person shooter material. The enviroments were spectacular, and it was a generally good game.

Sanctum 2, is an improvement of almost all aspects. First off, the teleport barriers that warped you back to spawn if you walked too far are gone. Meaning you can now fully explore each enviroment between waves, and this is great, because Sanctum 2 is absolutely gorgeous!

The loadout system has been slightly tweaked too, employing a new Class based system with preset weapons, and perks too. These are all unlocked through a progressive levelling system, which rewards playing, but can also be a little annoying at times. I feel most people will find it restrictive, but i personally think it allows you to specialise your character better, which is important, because combat has a much bigger role in this iteration.

Towers can get the job done, yes. But they are now also quite weaker, meaning if you want to hold off all waves you need to get down there yourself and take part in the fighting. Again, many will not enjoy this, and Tower Defence purists may be annoyed.

Pretty much the entire game has also been simplfied too. Towers now only have 3 levels, but you can insert more resources in order to overcharge" them and increase their stats more. Weapon levelling is now gone
date: instead relying on your loadout more. Standard block towers and offensive towers themselves now take seperate resources
recommended: meaning you can now build an effective maze and not worry about running out of resources.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: i thoroughly enjoy Sanctum 2
voteText: and highly recommend you purchase it if you own the first!"

reviewText:
Sanctum 2 doesn't offer much in the way of tutorial for new players, starting your right in the action. The most essential elements of gameplay are explained in mouseover tooltips, and after that it's just you and your strategy versus wave after wave of very hostile aliens.

Campaign storyline progress is provided in a comic book page style on each level's loading screen, and the levels start out pretty empty - it's up to you to decide how best to deploy your defenses based on what's coming next from the enemy direction.

Gameplay is balanced such that your towers don't quite dispatch all of the oncoming hostiles on their own - you'll need to go toe to toe with some heavy hitting bosses to keep your core safe.

Multiple gameplay modes and difficulties make this game challenging enough to be satisfying without being too hard to enjoy. This game has the distinction of being one of the few I've ever played where death isn't ruinously frustrating - if you die, you wait ten seconds to respawn and you jump blazing back into the action. I'd place my FPS skills at below average" on a good day
date: and I was still able to finish the campaign on my own in a few days.\n\nOverall
recommended: this game is an outstanding value
hoursPlayed: and a lot of fun!"

reviewText:
TL;DR:
While it's not a game for everyone, if you enjoyed tower defence but got bored with the monotony, get this game and hail the triumphant return of Tower Defence.

Full Review:
It was several years ago, and I'd had enough of the tower defence genre. With countless flash and mobile games that felt almost like carbon copies of each other, it had pretty much stagnated in my eyes. It looked as if the games I had once loved was dead.

And then I discovered Sanctum.

Sure, the internet connection I had at the time made it impossible for me to play co-op online, but with what little FPS skill I could muster I made due, and I absolutely loved it.

Flash-forward to late October 2013, when I found Sanctum 2 on sale. I immediately snapped it up and started playing, and I was far from dissapointed. Coffee Stain had used the 2 years between Sanctum and this game to truly make it worthy of being the sequel to the world’s first Tower Defense/FPS hybrid game."

For those of you that played the original
date: the biggest difference by far is the new resource system
recommended: which now has seperate units for constructing the tower bases that outline the maze and the towers that shoot the creeps ("Lumes"). New characters open up brand new strategies for demolishing the relentless horde. Gone now are the teleporter towers
hoursPlayed: now made pretty much unnesesary by smaller
voteText: more focused maps. Recycling towers also gives you all the credits put into them now
helpfulPercent: with the option to revert to only getting half your resources back avaliable in the "Hardcore Mode" Feat of Strength
votesHelpful: which also includes no respawn. There are other fairly large differences (was there a 15 tower limit in the original?)
votesTotal: but I found that they
commentsCount: actually added to the fun of the game so much I didn't actually care.\n\nFor those of you who haven't played the original
column16: this game is possibly the most rewarding co-op game I have ever played
column17: effortlessly combining high-brow Tower Defence strategy with fast-paced
column18: cooperative First Person Shooter action. So for those of you who
column20: became tired of simply observing your towers attempt to beat back the horde
column21: come join us. LOEK III can always use a few more Guardians."

reviewText: At an 85% discount, I would recommend this game to people who like tower defense. The weakspot mechanic and dumb-ish turret AI means you'll have to be active in protecting your base. Some consripts help as well, but most of the time you'll kill them yourself dropping bases on their heads to build towers on. Good thing they matter very little.\n\nThe Gameplay is fun, although it starts to get a bit repetitive some ways in. There is some enemy variety, in that new enemies are introduced periodically, however this game will also pull some This is a bigger version of the enemy therefore it's more tough" nonesense. A 10 second respawn timer means that you can die multiple times and not fail the stage
date: while being able to traverse the paths you made for the enemies unhindered is something I derived great pleasure from. One can have a maximum number of turrets down per stage (15 for the first areas
recommended: I did not check to see if this number is constant until the end)\n\nThe environments are nicely varied
hoursPlayed: each arena tastefully made. You can get out of the minimap-charted area to find some secrets and bonuses
voteText: often manifesting in the form of gimmicky "easter eggs" (such as an alarm when you pass through a security gate on a certain stage) or mines
helpfulPercent: which can be laid down to help you stem the flow of enemies. They do great damage
votesHelpful: but come in short supply.\n\nControls are nice and responsive
votesTotal: fully rebindable although the defaults are quite fine. Graphics are decent
votesFunny: though the enemy palette is a tad lacking
commentsCount: as lots of enemies share the same colours
column16: and every enemy has a primary colour that covers 90% of their bodies. However
column17: there are some nice details and the models themselves are quite unique. Each one also has its own little neat mechanic
column18: and the good animations means you'll know what's about to happen if you get too close to them. No instant-kill enemies
column19: as far as I can tell.\n\nThe game also has bosses on each area
column20: that add another layer of challenge. Some bosses can break your structures
column22: but the wave ends once you defeat them
column23: so it's not really an issue. I haven't played much
column24: but I liked what I saw thus far. Killing with the guns on offer is satisfying
column25: as they all have some sort of weight behind them
column26: and the guns are nicely varied

reviewText:
An interesting mix of FPS and tower defence. There is an emphasis on both, all though it feels more weighted towards an FPS - simply because that is your viewpoint into the game.

The soundtrack is sublime, and worth listening to offline to fully appreciate. The scenery, skyboxes and level design should be making most big name game developers weep with envy and jealousy.

A great game with plenty of replayability, with a good multiplayer community. Worth every penny and puts the majority of mainstream titles I've bought in the last few years to shame.

reviewText: This is one of the few games that delivers on everything it promises.  The single-player gameplay is good, but the game truly shines with it's flexible multiplayer.  It's very easy to drop in and out of a game or to invite other players into your own, and you'll never get stuck using a class you don't care for because the other three were taken.  The only downside to the multiplayer is that the chat is not easily accessible nor is it helpful when you're actually playing, even during the slow-paced build phases, but using a voice chat or being in the same room as the rest of your team is far better.  This is a game where buying the 4-pack is definitely the better option if you can't get it in a bundle

reviewText: Sanctum 2 is an enjoyable co-op game combining tower defense and FPS gameplay in a neat integrated package. You have a build phase during which you build your maze and deploy or upgrade tower weapons. This whole process is much more streamlined than the original game. Once your team is happy with the set up you activate the wave. Then it is shoot to kill using your own personal weapons. This part of the game is also more satisfying than the original because there seems to be less clumping of the enemies and therefore less Blast away without aiming" style gun play. The game is certainly well equipped to provide many evenings of inexpensive fun for a group of friends."

reviewText:
Sanctum 2 may be an indie game, but it looks, feels, sounds and plays like the finished product of a professional studio.

It's a highly polished and refreshingly unique experience that fixes all the mistakes of the previous game and offers DLC that's actually worth buying - all for a very reasonable price point.

I've played dozens of tower defense games that weren't worth paying for; I can say without hesitation that this one is.

reviewText: This game does a fantastic job combining the enjoyment of strategizing in a tower defense with the fast-paced action of a shooter. Unlike a lot of games that try to combine TD with another genre, one style tends to fall short of the other in terms of importance to game content and/or quality. That is not the case in Sanctum. I saw it as a bold move combining the slow meticulous strategy of tower defense with the fast-paced twitch style of FPS but this game knew what it was doing. The tower defense aspect is fun and engaging and not as slow and monotonous as it often is in games like Dungeon Defenders, while the FPS aspect is diverse and rewarding with a multitude of weapons and augmentations.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Mainly played this on multiplayer, and really enjoyed it.

Pros:
Fun blend of shooter and tower defence
Tower defence needs a decent amount of strategy
Shooter keeps you on your feet between building phases
Monster variation, weak spots and bosses keep the game interesting and challenging
Multiplayer with friends really gives that teamwork" and "divide-and-conquer" feel
Good variety of weapons
recommended: towers and skills\nTowers sell for full price
hoursPlayed:
allowing flexibility
Brilliant and fitting graphics
Absolutely awesome (fun and funny) text-to-voice chat
Friendly fire doesn't damage allies (technically)
Friendly fire can 'accidentally" push your friends off ledges and to their deaths (oops!)

Cons:
Friendly fire can accidentally push your friends off ledges and to their deaths
Difficulty varies
voteText:
and the space for mazing are extremely limited on some maps
Bosses are really really tough and may destroy towers
Losing at late stages in a game really sucks
There's a stage where (depending on which paths you block) ranged units can hit (and likely destroy) your core even before they enter your maze
helpfulPercent:
due to the map layout.

Tips:
Play with friends
Always prepare for air/final line of defence
Beware ranged units
Have one person take the core-healing perk
Kite bosses
If the round has a timer: build first
votesHelpful:
redo later
Don't rush monsters and end up in your allies' line of sight

Most Importantly:
Press "T" in-game and type something. Do it."

reviewText:
This is a great game no matter what it lacks or where it gets less perfect than i'd like it to be.  Plays well, and looks and sounds very - sometimes incredibly - pritty. It's got its places where you just stop to look ore listen, you know.
Maybe even a bit like made for girls. Yet i, as a 100% male do recommend it to everyone)).
It's got a generous variety of towers, guns, perks and 5 characters to play as, though i mostly played as Simo with sniper and assault rifles, good against all around towers like cannon, violator and focus(and one AA, if needed) and all three core-saving perks.
Beat its campaign as a singleplayer, now looking forward to a playthrough in a party. Ain't managed to complete everything with all feats of strength enabled, 1\3 or more are still to be beat on hardest difficulty along with the half of the achievements to be... achieved. It gets real tough sometimes or demands more idea about perks and towers than i've got for now, maybe. I think i've actually played it only half of the time recorded and about half of the time i played were failed replays on hardest.  And that didn't get too boring very fast.  So It's very involving and replayable.  Though i'd recommend not to try to break this game's neck replaying too many times in succession when it doesn't let you win a mission with all feats of strength enabled. That's how it becomes a time-waster.
Many thanks to Coffee Stain, i'll even think about purchasing that goat-simulator, damn it)). Right after i kick that BliskeBlaske(or whatever it's name) big flying rear part with all 5 FoS on)) or maybe sooner. Should you ever be planning to make more Sanctum games, please think about a shooter-slasher with much more passable space full of that beautiful alien nature, reids deep into the jungle, exploring abandoned settlements, attacks on the lumes' nests etc. With the same TD elements and perks, but optional - like a smaller core and some tower-bases and tower-guns dropped to support the team of characters and simo-units on a mission with the balance not crucially depending on fortifications. Could be great to play too. After all - we're not gonna give the whole planet back to lumes, right?))

reviewText: I only paid a couple of quid for this and at that price it's great value. Great idea but it falls between two stools: the shooting doesn't feel great and the tower defence part is a bit fiddly in first person. Also it's really designed for co-op play. Single player is frustrating with useless bots who will not fire on enemies even though they're right near them. It also defaults to making games public so if you don't want randoms joining in, turn it off. Great presentation, lots of customisation and options, but playing it on my own has been frustrating and a tad underwhelming, I'm afraid. Get some friends in if you do get this. I still recommend this is a decent co-op game.

reviewText:
I have played so many tower defenses games, whether on PC, consoles, or even iOS. But I have NEVER once played such a well-centered technological hybird FPS tower defense game.
I would highly recommend anyone that is interested in whether tower defenses games like Clash of Clans or technological games like BulletStorm to play this game.
The game is quite simple and casual, not too much confusion for beginners. By 1-3 days of playing Sanctum 2, you could possibly understand fully all the functions in-game.

reviewText:
At first this game isn't too special, the maps are very simple and getting new towers/abilities/weapons takes a while. But once you've hit the lv20ish range, chances are you'll have made your way to the more interesting maps and have plenty of stuff in your arsenal. The DLC also provides quite a few good maps that I liked better than the originals, along with two new towers in most of them.

Aside from the relatively slow leveling curve, there isn't really anything to complain about. Obviously it's better to play with others but luckily usually someone else who's made their way into at least the mid-teens knows what's going on and will recognize a good setup, so arguments over tower placement aren't an issue or at least haven't been much of one for me. Aside from some pair of two year-olds that muted me and wouldn't dare let me touch their sacred wall segments where they hadn't even placed turrets. Every game has some ♥♥♥♥♥♥s playing it, I suppose.

If you think whatever resources you're given after each wave are 'yours' then either drop the greedy mentality or don't even bother playing this game with anyone but yourself.

reviewText: There is so much that I love about this game I don't know where to begin.  The first Sanctum was a very good game in my opinion, but it had its shortcomings, most of which were remedied here in the sequel.  The new class system is so fantastic!  A TF2 addict like myself is going to love the classes.  The ability to jump over  your walls is very handy!  In the first Sanctum, you needed those lousy elevator whatcha-ma-call-ems to get over them.  The new character perk system trumps the old weapon upgrading system.  Who wants to have to deal with that each round? Jeez, I just want a simple layout, I'm here to shoot stuff! This sequel let's you focus your time on the towers, rather than having to allocate funds toward weapons each round.  One thing I really enjoy about S2 is that they give you just a small amount of towers each round instead of a bunch at the beginning.  This  has made co-op much quicker, and makes it seem more like a cooperative effort.  Believe me, the bickering about towers in the old Sanctum were so annoying.  There was always that artist" who wanted to create some amazing design
date: and it would take them FOREVER to finish it.\nBuy this game.  Its suits the shell-shocker and the logical strategist alike."

reviewText:
This game took me by surprise! It's a classic tower defense game that takes great advantage of the Unreal engine. You move around like its Unreal Tournament...which means double jumps and more. It also has a rich level system with loads of unlocks and specializations.

What's more, is that its geared towards multiplayer. I regularly have randoms jump into my games and its always good fun. That being said, a legit group with friends is always best.

Finally, the DLC is well worth it...as it adds more characters, weapons, towers, perks, etc. All-in-all, I spent <$3 on this game and I expect it'll rank up there with L4D2 as my go-to multiplayer FPS.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
At first I did not want to buy this game, the screenshots didnt look very promising. But then I got convinced by a friend and started playing it --- it's incredibly awesome, a must have for a tower defense fan like me.

It combines:
- tactical towerdefense with a lot of different and interesting towers, each one you can upgrade 3 times and then overcharge them, so they get even more powerful
- a kind of ego shooter to support your towers and a lot of possibilities to increase your strategy
- many different monsters with abilities and weak spots, making every one of them a challenge and worthy opponent
- a lot of hours of fun playing due to a long campaign and currently 4 addons, also a survival mode and hardcore-options
- multiplayer fun with up to 4 players

I just can recommend this game to everyone who loves strategy and tower defense.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Where do I even begin? I'm sure all gamers have at some point played a tower defense style game, but I have never seen a spin on it quite like this, it throws in the aspect of being a FPS, you have a character who gains experience and levels with each completed mission, leveling up increases you abilities and unlocks more weapons skills and slots for the like. Each map you start out by building walls and towers to defend your core, after you build with what you have availible you start the wave, so it still requires the strategy of funneling your enemies through mazes but also gives you the ability to run around and fight yourself. With the addition of boss battles it makes it more than the typical tower defence, the bosses have the power to smash your walls and towers which makes things more of a challenge, but the ability for 4 player co op lets you call for backup if you need a hand, Great game, decent price, lots of fun. (and it never hurts if you can catch it on the steam sale for $3.99)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: A bright, clever, witty and down right fun fps/tower defense hybrid. Improves on the original (which I played only briefly). A well prepared difficulty curved is nicely counterbalanced by unlocks including new weapons, turrets and perks. The art direction is unique, evoking cartoons and water colors while still retaining a sense of place. Most importantly the gameplay is fun and only get's better when you add more players. Buy this game and play it with friends. The only things I would add is a slightly deeper story and maybe some unlimited skirmish type modes (which may or may not exist at the end game already). 8.5/10

reviewText: As a fan of the original Sanctum, playing this game can feel a little weird. Firstly, you're far more limited on towers, with you starting off only being able to deploy/upgrade 1 kind of tower and can get a max of 4 as you progress. You also only have 2 weapons. Before you had a giant blank canvas to develop into a maze of towers with your core WAY off at the end, now your core is almost in the middle of things. So if you've developed tactics from the first game, they won;t fly in this one. Instead of a ton of towers, you're better off with a few that get a lot of upgrades. And instead of only really needing to shoot a few special enemies, now you're gonna be in the thick of it, so pick your weapons carefully.\n\nHonetly, from what I've seen this game takes Sanctum in a direction that it seemed to be heading for anyway. The first was almsot all about tower placement and maze formation, while this game gives the FPS elements more of the spotlight. The two work well together despite what you'd think, and it adds a level of tactical gameplay with the limiting of towers and weapons not to mention character selection since each has their own signiture weapon and defauly bonuses.

reviewText:
This game is very good, yet lacking in some respects.

Sanctum 2 is a very multiplayer oriented game. If you don't have at least another person with you you will have a challenge and the game will just be less enjoyable in general. Though I say this, this game is a very unique genre, blending FPS with tower defense games, a genre normally reserved for crappy flash games. After a while though, you tend to realize that the best strategy is to set up a fortress of turrets at your exit, making the game extremely easy. Slightly flawed as it is, this game is fun and has some good moments and deserved to be tried out.

8.5/10

reviewText:
This is a great game no matter what it lacks or where it gets less perfect than i'd like it to be.  Plays well, and looks and sounds very - sometimes incredibly - pritty. It's got its places where you just stop to look ore listen, you know.
Maybe even a bit like made for girls. Yet i, as a 100% male do recommend it to everyone)).
It's got a generous variety of towers, guns, perks and 5 characters to play as, though i mostly played as Simo with sniper and assault rifles, good against all around towers like cannon, violator and focus(and one AA, if needed) and all three core-saving perks.
Beat its campaign as a singleplayer, now looking forward to a playthrough in a party. Ain't managed to complete everything with all feats of strength enabled, 1\3 or more are still to be beat on hardest difficulty along with the half of the achievements to be... achieved. It gets real tough sometimes or demands more idea about perks and towers than i've got for now, maybe. I think i've actually played it only half of the time recorded and about half of the time i played were failed replays on hardest.  And that didn't get too boring very fast.  So It's very involving and replayable.  Though i'd recommend not to try to break this game's neck replaying too many times in succession when it doesn't let you win a mission with all feats of strength enabled. That's how it becomes a time-waster.
Many thanks to Coffee Stain, i'll even think about purchasing that goat-simulator, damn it)). Right after i kick that BliskeBlaske(or whatever it's name) big flying rear part with all 5 FoS on)) or maybe sooner. Should you ever be planning to make more Sanctum games, please think about a shooter-slasher with much more passable space full of that beautiful alien nature, reids deep into the jungle, exploring abandoned settlements, attacks on the lumes' nests etc. With the same TD elements and perks, but optional - like a smaller core and some tower-bases and tower-guns dropped to support the team of characters and simo-units on a mission with the balance not crucially depending on fortifications. Could be great to play too. After all - we're not gonna give the whole planet back to lumes, right?))

reviewText:
Sanctum 2 is a game combining tower-defense concepts with a first-person shooter. Taking place in a futuristic world, join with up to 3 other people (4 player co-op) to defend waves after waves of the biggest bunch of bugs you've probably seen lately. Featuring a large vareity of towers, weapons and perks across multiple maps, Sanctum 2 is definately a game to look at. Multiple types of enemies will force you to think of new innovative strategies to stop them from destorying your core, accompanied by a well-designed world and characters.
The game also has a leveling system that will motivate you to keep playing in order to open new stages, and also allows you to set higher or lower difficulties if you feel the game is too easy/hard. (And believe, it can be VERY hard)
The story is quite dull and there is a lot of DLC, and a few balancing issues still exist, but still, Sanctum 2 is definately one of the best tower-defense games out there, so you don't want to miss on that classic.

So get ready! It's time to save the world!

reviewText: Awesome mix of genres, it makes me wish I never bought Dungeon Defenders but that doesn't take much. This FPTDS (First Person Tower Defense Shooter) combines strategy and the FPS into an alien killing frenzy. The excitement as a new wave comes, frantically defending the core using fun weaponary and damagin towers. Levelling up also unlocks new possibilities: new perks, weapons and towers. Feats of strength are there when you fancy a challenge and the comic style story clips make this game unique, to think it is an indie game amazes me. A good entry to FPS games for those to young to play realistic ones as it is a 12, but still enjoyable as you mow down hoardes of interesting new aliens with a gun that shoots pure electricity.\n\n7/10

reviewText:
Sanctum 1 was a tower defense game with FPS mechanics.  Sanctum 2 has much more limited maze design opportunities but adds Borderlands-style class mechanics with perks, different loadouts, etc.   This changed the game a lot which seems to have upset a lot of Sanctum 1 purists.  However, the changes actually justify the sequel since they amount to a huge overhaul of the game and not simply a slight modification of the original.

The game is designed well, controls well, and runs pretty well.  I've had very occasional glitches but it's better than par for the most part.

Sanctum 2 ends up being much more fun in multiplayer than singleplayer - so much so that I'd really only recommend getting it if you have a friend or two to play with.  That said, it is REALLY fun in mutliplayer and since you can often pick it up for $5 per copy, it's great value.

reviewText: This game is wonderful fun.  It's a simple concept - FPS Tower Defense.  You don't really have much crossover between the two genres - you set up your towers before the wave starts, then swap to weapons and help the towers blow things up during the wave.  There is also a little bit of character customization - not enough to actually create builds, but little things like choosing which weapons and towers to take with you in to battle does create different play styles for different people.\n\nBasically, if you want to shoot a bunch of aliens that are crawling through a maze of turrets you built, this is your game.

reviewText: This game. This game is so good. It expands on many of the features of the first game and feels more like an actual game, rather than a bunch of maps to select from. In order to unlock new towers, you need to level up by playing through the maps and gaining exp from killing sh*t, which is a great featureso you feel as though you are getting stronger along with your foes (but it's done in a way that you can still get the crap beaten out of your core and lose, despite your shiny new towers), and the devs even added in a perk feature, which I didn't feel was needed until I used it and fell in love with it. You can unlock more perk slots and equip up to 4 at the beginning of each map, and holy crap they're awesome. The perks range from increasing the damage inflicted on enemy weakspots (I always equip that one), to having the core regain 10% of it's max health after each round, to you shooting lightning out of your body or jumping on an enemy and inflicting 2000 damage (Plumber Shoes ftw) or even increasing the amount of damage you inflict by 15% for every enemy near you. These perks are an amazing addition, and are super fun and add a bunch of variety to each game you play (especially on co-op, with each player equipping different perks).\nNow if you read that and are thinking, Hmmm.... Sounds like I'm going to be overpowered.... Especially on co-op
date:
and you couldn't be more WRONG. The game is really tough, as the towers now do less damage than in the first game and you have to play a larger role in combatting the hordes of mobs you will find in this game. One moment you're on top of the world, your maze is obliterating everything, and the next you have a giant Super Heavy blowing up your towers (and yes, certain boss enemies can destroy your towers, but they can be repaired for free after the round) and a huge swarm of walker pups are attacking your core. Something about the constant switch from success to failure makes the game really addicting, and can you keep playing when you could've rage quit earlier, simply because THIS turret layout is going to work, forget the four you built before. This is the one, and thats what keeps you going.
I haven't completed the game's campaign, or come anywhere near unlocking all the perks (I'm only level 12 out of 50 I think), mainly cuz I only play this game for hour bursts when I want to blow off steam after work or whatever (sometimes i binge and play for longer; 6 hours straight was the longest I could go before getting off and that was so I could go to work), and that's exactly what this game is made for. The original was good, but a lot of the maps were too long requiring you to beat 20 or 25 long waves of enemies before completing the map. In this game there are 8 (with all the DLC) regions, each one with about 4 or 5 maps inside of it (which is a lot of content), and each map contains about 10-15 waves which is a lot easier to get through than 20 or 25 in the original. Because of this the maps change often enough to stay interesting and visually appealing (they're all beautifully designed and full of little secrets like playable arcade games), and the graphics are really breath taking as the environments go from clean cities, to rusted out junkyards and train stations, to beautiful, alien forests (and more areas I haven't seen before) which are completely gorgeous on the Unreal engine this game uses.
As you've noticed earlier, I've been comparing this game to the original which I'm assuming you've already played. If not buy both of them and play them now (there's no story in the first game, so if you can only afford one, buy this one). If you were a fan of the original but read negative reviews saying the game is watered down and dumber, that is 100% untrue. Out of the entire game I can find only 1 issue, which is when you upgrade the cannon tower that tower does less than DPS than if you just bought another cannon and put it by the first one. Other than that though, the game is improved in every way. Graphically, the first game was really nice for an indy game with burnt out cities and gorgeous jungles, but this game takes the cake. Gameplay-wise, this game is far superior. It feels like a spectacular molding of excellant FPS gameplay mixed with tower defense and not TD with FPS thrown in as a novelty or vice versa. Story, the second one actually has a story now, told through little entertaining comic strips that are shown as each map loads. I haven't gotten far in the story at all, but so far so good. It's not the focus of the game, but it's nice to see all the playable characters interacting and learn some backstory on the Lumes (the enemies you'll face) and Elysion One. Music: As an owner of the Sanctum 1 soundtrack, I have to admit the first game has better music, but the music in 2 is still very strong and very good. However it is one of those soundtracks you dont notice, which a lot of people consider to be the best type, so it's good.
Overall, I recommend this game to anyone with a PC and a love for gaming. It's that good. It requires the fast reflexes and thinking of a well-made shooter (not COD), but also the calculating logic of a TD, and the creativity of building games. I may not be the most qualified to write this review, as I stated before, I'm not far in the game, but there is just so much content and so far it is all so good I can't help but write this review now, so others will dive into the world of Elysion One and kick more Lume a$$. I'll probably edit this review (if i can) when I complete this game, but as of now I am currently having a love affair with this game.

Would Recommend in an instant.
10/10

reviewText: Where do I even begin? I'm sure all gamers have at some point played a tower defense style game, but I have never seen a spin on it quite like this, it throws in the aspect of being a FPS, you have a character who gains experience and levels with each completed mission, leveling up increases you abilities and unlocks more weapons skills and slots for the like. Each map you start out by building walls and towers to defend your core, after you build with what you have availible you start the wave, so it still requires the strategy of funneling your enemies through mazes but also gives you the ability to run around and fight yourself. With the addition of boss battles it makes it more than the typical tower defence, the bosses have the power to smash your walls and towers which makes things more of a challenge, but the ability for 4 player co op lets you call for backup if you need a hand, Great game, decent price, lots of fun. (and it never hurts if you can catch it on the steam sale for $3.99)

reviewText:
At first this game isn't too special, the maps are very simple and getting new towers/abilities/weapons takes a while. But once you've hit the lv20ish range, chances are you'll have made your way to the more interesting maps and have plenty of stuff in your arsenal. The DLC also provides quite a few good maps that I liked better than the originals, along with two new towers in most of them.

Aside from the relatively slow leveling curve, there isn't really anything to complain about. Obviously it's better to play with others but luckily usually someone else who's made their way into at least the mid-teens knows what's going on and will recognize a good setup, so arguments over tower placement aren't an issue or at least haven't been much of one for me. Aside from some pair of two year-olds that muted me and wouldn't dare let me touch their sacred wall segments where they hadn't even placed turrets. Every game has some ♥♥♥♥♥♥s playing it, I suppose.

If you think whatever resources you're given after each wave are 'yours' then either drop the greedy mentality or don't even bother playing this game with anyone but yourself.

reviewText: There is so much that I love about this game I don't know where to begin.  The first Sanctum was a very good game in my opinion, but it had its shortcomings, most of which were remedied here in the sequel.  The new class system is so fantastic!  A TF2 addict like myself is going to love the classes.  The ability to jump over  your walls is very handy!  In the first Sanctum, you needed those lousy elevator whatcha-ma-call-ems to get over them.  The new character perk system trumps the old weapon upgrading system.  Who wants to have to deal with that each round? Jeez, I just want a simple layout, I'm here to shoot stuff! This sequel let's you focus your time on the towers, rather than having to allocate funds toward weapons each round.  One thing I really enjoy about S2 is that they give you just a small amount of towers each round instead of a bunch at the beginning.  This  has made co-op much quicker, and makes it seem more like a cooperative effort.  Believe me, the bickering about towers in the old Sanctum were so annoying.  There was always that artist" who wanted to create some amazing design
date: and it would take them FOREVER to finish it.\nBuy this game.  Its suits the shell-shocker and the logical strategist alike."

reviewText:
Man, Sanctum 2 is one of my favorite games of all time. The guys that made Goat Simulator made this game first, and it sure is a gem that should be played by everyone. I love how it uses the tower defense genre simultaneously with some first-person shooter gameplay, and without any of the clutter many games like Orcs Must Die and PVZ: Garden Warefare have shown. There's some basic class customization that's simple but changes each level's approach immensely. Also, multiplayer is awesome, especially in later levels where teamwork is key to victory. I didn't buy the DLC, but I know I should have since it unlocks tons of valuable features that are definitely worth the extra cash. Hilarious and interactive easter eggs can be found all over the normal looking levels too. One level actually has a full-on arcade in the sky where you can play mini-games, it's awesome. Grab some friends to play with, and check this game out if you haven't yet.

Rating: 10/10
Recommended Price: $15

reviewText:
Sanctum 2 is a really fun and challenging game where you will often need the help of your friends or the rest of the community to complete the maps.

The game takes place in a futuristic world where you take the role of one of four core guardians. Your task is to protect the cores from advancing waves of alien monsters called lumes. The storyline is very nice and well worth following to learn more about the cores and the lumes so I won't spoil it for you. To your help you have a wide array of different towers, weapons and perks and every level you unlock new goodies to use!

The game has 4 available DLCs and I recommend them all as well as they all add new lumes, weapons, towers and perks. All 4 DLCs combined provide as much content as the original game!

reviewText:
Though I've had my fair share of bugs and crash issues with this game, I have had a great experience with it.

The game accomplishes something that's truly rare in gaming. It is incredibly challenging at times, but always makes you feel as though you and your party are at fault when you fail a mission rather than the game itself feeling cheap or like the AI is way overpowered.

The shooting mechanics are passable, but the depth with the perks and towers are where the game really shines. Paired with one or two party members, you really begin to find great combinations that can prove effective against the multitude of enemies and map designs you'll have to fight through each mission.

reviewText: If you liked Sanctum or are interested in tower defense games then you will probably love Sanctum 2! On top of what the original offers, it has new maps and several new enemies, weapons, and towers. Even cooler are some of the other new additions: you now get to select one of 4 characters/classes each time you play, the characters gain levels, and other than weapons and towers you also get abilities for your character to customize them further to your style. They also made coop play easier, and you can play any of the maps or campaign solo or with friends, or join other random players if you want. They also added some challenge parameters you can toggle if you choose like increasing the speed of the enemies or giving them regeneration and so on. Definitely worth picking up.

reviewText:
This game took me by surprise! It's a classic tower defense game that takes great advantage of the Unreal engine. You move around like its Unreal Tournament...which means double jumps and more. It also has a rich level system with loads of unlocks and specializations.

What's more, is that its geared towards multiplayer. I regularly have randoms jump into my games and its always good fun. That being said, a legit group with friends is always best.

Finally, the DLC is well worth it...as it adds more characters, weapons, towers, perks, etc. All-in-all, I spent <$3 on this game and I expect it'll rank up there with L4D2 as my go-to multiplayer FPS.

reviewText:
I have one version for people who played the original, and for those new to the series. I'll begin with the part for those who played the first.

If You Played the First Sanctum:
Buy this. If you had any fun on it, buy this. The addition of player health, ammunition, and maximum limit on blocks might be a turn off, and I know it was for me. Nonetheless, I bought it on a sale, because why not? I was not disappointed. After completing the game, I can say with certainty that this game is far superior to the last one. Trust me, buy it.

For Those New to the Series:
Sanctum 2 is the sequel to the popular game Sanctum, a tower defense game taken to a new direction. It combined FPS elements with tower defense and strategy, as you built mazes to slow progress of monsters travelling on the shortest route to reach the Core, your point of protection. You played down with the blocks/towers, shooting the enemies, sometimes enabling the towers to do damage to them (since a small number of them required to be hit with high damage in a small area to be able to be hit by towers). It was very fun (for me), and I spent hours on it with friends. This game adds restrictions to the maze building system, making it more balanced and fair. It also has new characters, weapons, abilities, enemies, maps, and gameplay improvements. Watch a few videos on YouTube, and if it seems like your cup of tea, buy it, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Mainly played this on multiplayer, and really enjoyed it.

Pros:
Fun blend of shooter and tower defence
Tower defence needs a decent amount of strategy
Shooter keeps you on your feet between building phases
Monster variation, weak spots and bosses keep the game interesting and challenging
Multiplayer with friends really gives that teamwork" and "divide-and-conquer" feel
Good variety of weapons
recommended: towers and skills\nTowers sell for full price
hoursPlayed:
allowing flexibility
Brilliant and fitting graphics
Absolutely awesome (fun and funny) text-to-voice chat
Friendly fire doesn't damage allies (technically)
Friendly fire can 'accidentally" push your friends off ledges and to their deaths (oops!)

Cons:
Friendly fire can accidentally push your friends off ledges and to their deaths
Difficulty varies
voteText:
and the space for mazing are extremely limited on some maps
Bosses are really really tough and may destroy towers
Losing at late stages in a game really sucks
There's a stage where (depending on which paths you block) ranged units can hit (and likely destroy) your core even before they enter your maze
helpfulPercent:
due to the map layout.

Tips:
Play with friends
Always prepare for air/final line of defence
Beware ranged units
Have one person take the core-healing perk
Kite bosses
If the round has a timer: build first
votesHelpful:
redo later
Don't rush monsters and end up in your allies' line of sight

Most Importantly:
Press "T" in-game and type something. Do it."

I have one version for people who played the original, and for those new to the series. I'll begin with the part for those who played the first.

If You Played the First Sanctum:
Buy this. If you had any fun on it, buy this. The addition of player health, ammunition, and maximum limit on blocks might be a turn off, and I know it was for me. For Those New to the Series:
Sanctum 2 is the sequel to the popular game Sanctum, a tower defense game taken to a new direction. It combined FPS elements with tower defense and strategy, as you built mazes to slow progress of monsters travelling on the shortest route to reach the Core, your point of protection. You played down with the blocks/towers, shooting the enemies, sometimes enabling the towers to do damage to them (since a small number of them required to be hit with high damage in a small area to be able to be hit by towers). It was very fun (for me), and I spent hours on it with friends. This game adds restrictions to the maze building system, making it more balanced and fair. It also has new characters, weapons, abilities, enemies, maps, and gameplay improvements. Watch a few videos on YouTube, and if it seems like your cup of tea, buy it, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
I'm not comparing this to Sanctum 1, because I never got through the first few levels of it.  I also typically don't like tower defense, and while this game is an exception, it also means I'll probably miss the finer points that a TD nerd would happily point out.  The 7300+ positive reviews massively outweighing the 700+ negative reviews should probably tell you something.

The graphics are simple, clean, and flashy, and what little voice acting there is is pretty well done.  Unlike the previous title this game has an actual story, told through comic-style  stills inebetween levels.  While I wrote better dialogue when I was in high school, it was nice to have some kind of setting, something a lot of tower defense games don't bother with.

Each character has a different passive ability.  There are eventually 20 towers total, 16 weapons, which with enough levels, can be swapped out to any pair on a single character.  There are also 63 perks altogether.  Some of these items are only obtained through the DLC.  Altogether, the DLC effectively doubles the size of the game, so even if they didn't contain weapons and perks are absolutely worth getting.

Many different synergies exist between the combination of equipped towers, weapons, and perks.  The game supports up to 4 players, and everyone has their own loadouts and resources, but they share the same tower limit from single player.

Speaking of that, the game can be very challenging to solo.  I was stuck on some maps for hours, but I persevered.  The balance is reflected in the fact that only once or twice did I have to grind out some levels for a tower or weapon to make enough difference for me to get past certain areas.  Even then it was probably unnecessary.

Once you're done with that, up to five feats of strength" can be enabled per level to increase xp and make the game tougher.  At its most basic
date: expect to get stuck on half a dozen of the game's levels
hoursPlayed: like Dark Souls
voteText: expect a generous rush when you complete a level you were sure was impossible to solo.\n\nThe game isn't perfect
helpfulPercent: but I would pay full price for the total package."
votesHelpful: September 24, 2015

reviewText:
One of the best cooperative games out there for sure. The FPS is clunky at first but gets very smooth when you learn it.
Map variety is not huge, the theme however is very vibrant, and the monster variety- well, the variety of how to kill monsters, are quite good. Not to mention, this is clearly a Tower Defense game too, but dont forget your character can shoot, and it really comes in to play if you're a good player or not by the way you setup perks and shoot, rather than letting your towers do all work. There is TONS of hours you could sink in to this with friends to play with. I also recommend to buy the game from a third party, cause you can basically get the whole package with all DLC's for most likely cheaper.

reviewText:
I played it on the Free Weekend it went on a while ago, expecting it to be just your regular run and gun fps, and boy was I wrong.
Serious review here, people.
Sanctum 2 looks like your average sci-fi shooter, but it is SO much more.
You place towers with guns to protect this electric sphere thingie called the Core, which, if destroyed, makes you lose.
There are four characters in this game, one of which is a sniper robot that uses memes as faces.
The other three are your basic classes.
Close range with shotgun, just a basic class with an assault rifle, and EXPLODEZEZ EVERYWHEREZ with a rocket launcher.
But it DOES have its problems. None of which I can exactly remember right now.. So...
Thats a review.
10/10 would Tower Defense again.

Map variety is not huge, the theme however is very vibrant, and the monster variety- well, the variety of how to kill monsters, are quite good. Not to mention, this is clearly a Tower Defense game too, but dont forget your character can shoot, and it really comes in to play if you're a good player or not by the way you setup perks and shoot, rather than letting your towers do all work. There is TONS of hours you could sink in to this with friends to play with. I also recommend to buy the game from a third party, cause you can basically get the whole package with all DLC's for most likely cheaper.

Ahem, hint hint G33 two A (you know what i mean).

reviewText: I cautiously recommend this game.  I like being a player inside a tower defense game and would recommend Orcs Must Die 2 or Dungeon Defenders over this one.  Sanctum 2 isn't bad, in fact it is good, just there are games out there with similar gameplay elements that are better.  If someone were committed to the space/future theme over the magic/fantasy theme, the mechanical/technical feel of Sanctum 2 might appeal to them more, though I feel the Halo-clone enemies in Sanctum 2 lose out in how they lack the whimsy of fighting hordes of cartoony goblins as one does in Orcs Must Die 2.

reviewText:
Man, Sanctum 2 is one of my favorite games of all time. The guys that made Goat Simulator made this game first, and it sure is a gem that should be played by everyone. I love how it uses the tower defense genre simultaneously with some first-person shooter gameplay, and without any of the clutter many games like Orcs Must Die and PVZ: Garden Warefare have shown. There's some basic class customization that's simple but changes each level's approach immensely. Also, multiplayer is awesome, especially in later levels where teamwork is key to victory. I didn't buy the DLC, but I know I should have since it unlocks tons of valuable features that are definitely worth the extra cash. Hilarious and interactive easter eggs can be found all over the normal looking levels too. One level actually has a full-on arcade in the sky where you can play mini-games, it's awesome. Grab some friends to play with, and check this game out if you haven't yet.

Rating: 10/10
Recommended Price: $15

reviewText:
Really fun hybrid/FPS TD game.

Before the level you pick your character, weapon and the perks and towers you want to equip. You also unlock more as you rank up and can gain more xp with applying buffs (feats of strength) to give you bonus XP. Before the waves start you run around building the blocks/foundations and then spend money to build the towers you've equipped in the loadout or upgrade them. Then you start the wave and while the towers you built are doing their job you just run around blowing up alien-like creatures and gunning them down.

I love TD games/maps and this is really fun! Even better I got this for $3 USD on the Lunar sale instead of $15.  Still worth it either way, though. It's a must-buy, especially at sale price.

Pros:
-Fun as fun can be
-Graphics are decent and pretty, nice environment and textures.
-Running around blowing things up while towers work is fun.
-Maze maze maze.
-Heaps of perks and towers to unlock.
-Can play solo, co-op or online. Private or public.
-Bosses can smash your towers so prioritise them or build empty blocks on the outer perimeter.

Cons:
-Difficulty scaling isn't perfect. I'm not sure if it scales with more players if you play online/co-op. Starting levels were quite hard, middle levels quite easy,
-Needs more content, although the game is cheap.
-Repetitive like most TD games, not too[/] much though, just that there's not much different strats you can do, although tactical juxtaposition perk can change things up a bit.

reviewText:
Compared to Sanctum 1 this focuses a bit more on the shooter part than the tower defense part. Some of the new changes are nice (characters, weapons, leveling), others need a little work (timed build phase, resource management). Still a fun hybrid of First Person Shooter and Tower Defense.

Seems like a lot of people who think it sucks just  wanted an updated Sanctum 1 and didn't bother to look into the game before buying it. The resources and tower limit were both known about before release. The resources definitely needs work, would like to see a few more towers available each wave as well. The tower limit makes you think of placement even more, and I have only hit the cap once so far.

Would recommend buying the game but waiting on the Season Pass for now.

reviewText: I really like the concept of this game.  The ability to move blocks and towers, and swap out towers without penalty, are great touches.  The game was completely different from what I was expecting, and I wish I would have heard of this game sooner.  I love finding a game that introduces me to something new and enjoyable.  Simple and enjoyable.  The maps vary enough to keep things from becoming too redundant.  I like that I can go back to previous maps, and try to set my own goals, such as: fewest blocks and towers used, all turrets, all ground pounders, nothing but blocks, and anything else that creates a challenge.  I really enjoy standing at the exit of a long maze of turrets, just blasting away at those mobs that thought they were going to make it to the end.  Chain-reaction exploding mobs anyone?

reviewText:
On the surface, Sanctum 2 is a basic tower defense shooter, with much better than indie graphics and voice overs (I want to marry Sweet), and a strange fixation on irrelevant details (why all this modeling of bars and security points that have nothing to do with the game?).  In contrast to Dungeon Grinders.. I mean Defenders, Sanctum eschews the farming and looting in favor of straight game play.  It does have experience and levels, but they're mostly a minor annoyance.  Like DD, the first person shooter element isn't strongly emphasized as the enemies are all very predictable and tower placement usually dominates your chances of success.

Where Sanctum really shines is the point after you've beaten the normal levels by randomly throwing down some towers and running wildly around blasting everything.  Flip on all the bad guy boosts and suddenly you have a very serious co-op puzzle game.  Which perks to take, what guns, and how to lay out your towers become hard questions, with different answers for every map.  Climbing the leaderboard becomes a competitive challenge.

If you enjoy cooperatively solving hard optimization problems, I strongly recommend Sanctum 2 with a friend.

Sanctum 2 does have some weak points.  The experience/level system just gets in the way and should've been scrapped.    There are too many perks and even when you know them all, it can be hard to find the one you want.  Number of players scaling is sometimes a factor.  Hoard avoided this by having specific maps for specific numbers of players.  Sanctum tries to pretend boosting the health of enemies is close enough.  It isn't and it makes leaderboard comparisons problematic.  The mind control tower introduced in the dlc substantially changes the game and ruins the leaderboard for people without the dlc.  The developers should've had separate ladders for dlc and without.

reviewText:
It is impossible to deny that Coffee Stain Studios took just about everything good in Sanctum and amped it up tenfold for Sanctum 2.
Enhancing the coop mode by adding three new player characters alongside the original protagonist, each specializing in one of four weapon categories (Assault Rifles, Snipers, Shotguns and a big happy rocket launcher that blinds the entire right side of your screen).
Like the previous title, Sanctum 2 is a fast-paced FPS tower defense game that requires a heavy load of brainpower to keep the waves of alien enemies away from your core. In Sanctum 2 the challenge level is increased, giving the player less resources after each wave and removing the ability to upgrade weapons with resources, forcing the player to focus less on weapon damage and instead on carefully placed towers, walls and turrets to keep the enemy waves back, as well as the addition of a timer to mix things up and make the waves more chaotic.
With an immersive campaign mode playable in both single player or coop, Sanctum 2 offers mind-blowing gameplay complimented with a level-up system that rewards the player with unlockable towers, weapons and perks as well as a digital comic that offers insight into Sanctum's world which reveals a page or two before every stage.
Sanctum 2 is a direct upgrade to Sanctum, and is well worth the time for any fans of the original.

reviewText:
If you aren't devoted, you'll just give up on later levels. There IS a lot of replay value, but I wasn't devoted, so I just left it in my pile of games. If you get this game while you have a lot of other games that you play often, you'll probably just leave this. Get this once you're bored of other games and want to be devoted to something new. Onto gameplay.

This game is a mix between Tower Defense and FPS games. It sounds bad on paper, but it holds it ground well. The graphics are impressive, gameplay is fun, and it still maintains challenging. Sometimes, a bit too challenging, though.

The 4 (5 with DLC) characters offer a good form of diversity between players, not to mention the many other weapons and upgrades you can unlock later. Again, added replay bonus.

The DLC is more levels, plus a new character. If you don't want more levels that badly, and are comfortable with one character, don't get it.

In the end, don't get bored of it, and it'll reward you.

reviewText:
Underrated game. I think this game would have a lot of potential to hold a strong userbase if they had focused on more multiplayer things, like ramping up the difficulty in ways other than hp or maybe something like a vs mode.

If you like tower defense you'll like this game. Tower defense is the core of the game. If you like FPS but don't like tower defense so much, you probably will get bored. The FPS aspect is very central to the game, but there are ways to make it easy to have an impact even if you're no good at fps games at all (drone launcher + tactical juxtaposition on sweet, anyone?)

I'd recommend it. If for nothing else, then for the robot voices that read chat in multiplayer.

reviewText: I have mixed feelings about this game. I still recommend you buy it, especially if you played the first game, but let's go over a few new details. In Sanctum 1, it was all about the towers and a lovely first person tower defense game...however, in Sanctum 2 there are tons of changes from the first game that make it more of a challenge and overall different feel compared to the first game. You get a limit on how many towers can place, they cost more, they are harder to upgrade, and it relies on you to kill most of the enemies with the towers as support instead of vice versa from the original game. To me, I had to rethink and form almost completely new strategies for this game. That being said, it is still a fantastic, albeit difficult, game. The maps are all new with beautiful design to them, and many of which can allow you to go back and play them again by creating a new path they may be better than your original to lead the Lumes (enemies) through. The towers in this game are familiar with the first one with a couple of new editions. Also there are 4 characters you can play as and customize with various perks, weapons, and towers for endless possibilities strategically. Some maps are more difficult than others and will frustrate you as they did me. Sometimes I'm led to believe this game was meant to be played with others through co-op in order to beat the levels, but then I find a new plan that works and even though it may be hard, you can solo this game should you wish. Overall, I give this game a solid 8 out of 10 if I had to, and I recommend it to those of you who love real time strategy, FPS, and/or tower defense games. This game just has it all wrapped into one. Also, I strongly recommend it to those of you who are in need of a game outside of TF2 and looking for another great multiplayer game you can play together and have some fun. The single-player side is great--don't misunderstand--, but that feeling of success when shared with friends after beating a level makes it oh-so-much-more satisfying.

reviewText: So the premise of this game is that humans have established colonies in the skies over an alien planet. They use magical blue balls of light (cores) to convert the gasses present into oxygen and kill the native spores. The problem is that the planet is already occupied by an alien race of highly evolved mushrooms. The mushroom people under the direction of unknown telepathic boss entity whom you never fight create giant organic shafts to the colonies to try to murder them dead.\n\nIn the game you will create a maze of towers in an attempt to halt the advance of the mushroom people before they destroy you're magical blue ball as is typical of a Tower Defense game. you will spend 5, 10 or 15 minutes per level depositing towers that will ultimately only do about thirty percent of the damage necessary to kill the enemy waves. The rest is up to you. You can choose two of a plethora of weapons to aid you in the struggle. The game does not address why a gun held by a five foot two to six foot tall human out damages half dozen tool shed sized tower mounted guns you drop and arguably that means this game isn't really a TD. There are perks" you can select to improve you're characters/towers performance but there’s really nothing that will turn this game into an actual Tower Defense
date: which is unfortunate.\n\nThe longer you play the game the more powerful guns
recommended: perks and towers you can unlock
hoursPlayed: particularly if you buy the DLC. I'm sure we all know the DLC drill by now. For an extra five dollars you will get access to all the content that was cut from the game during the alpha and beta tests for quality control and balance reasons. Ideally that content has since been fixed/balanced/polished but we never know until we shell out the cash. To their credit the DLC for Sanctum 2 does provide a lot of interesting content. The towers
voteText:
perks and maps it adds do a great deal to increase replayability of the game and it rounds out the base games story that ends on a cliffhanger.

The real strength of this game is the level design. Like every other piece of science fiction made in the past twelve years almost everything looks like an Ipod that said this game does it particularly well. The integration of organic vines and spores growing over the utopian surfaces/structures in this game are very imaginative and well done. A lot of games (Doom 3/Dead Space) place a strong aesthetic emphasis in a human environment being reverse terraformed by some perverse alien influence but truthfully Sanctum 2 does it better. The levels are distinct from each other in groups as you proceed from an idealistic lived in colony under attack to the deteriorating front lines to an industrial themed colony abandoned some years or generations earlier. The theme is that the further into the game you go the closer to the planet you get until ultimately you are beneath its surface in a giant cavern with mushroom Jesus. In the tradition of classic FPS games there are many many secret areas and players are rewarded for their diligent exploration. Ironically the maps are far bigger in scope then the developers were prepared to work with and you’ll shudder when you realize that you can’t incorporate some of the games incredibly ideal choke points into you’re defense as they are simply too far away from where the action will be…. If they allowed you to place your own cores the quality of the game would quadruple immediately but thats something they will have to consider for a sequel.

The biggest issue with the game is the many many clipping errors. This game will kill you or force you to consul command suicide many times as you fall through solid objects or get stuck between them. In the basic game it doesn’t matter very much as you can wait out the 9 second respawn time once or twice and it isn’t likely to lose the game for you. Tragically the developers compounded this issue by encouraging the players to play with “five feats of strength” on to create a more challenging experience… One of these “feats” is a no respawn mode…  So basically each time you die to a developer error
helpfulPercent: which will be once or twice a game
votesHelpful: you’ll also lose the level. Since playing with the feats of strength on is going to be your last real experience with the game they are brutally poisoning their consumer base who will only remember losing 30 minutes of an expertly played game because Coffe Stain Studio's didn’t properly patch or beta test. Hardcore modes are made for polished games made by hardcore developers. It might be a tough pill for Coffee Stain Studios to swallow but they just haven’t reached that point yet.\n\nFor ten dollars it is a really cool indie game. The maps if not always utilized ideally are a clever visual spectacle and it does have a lot of replay value. If Coffee Stain Studio focuses on adding general content to their games and take their player testers a little more seriously these guys could easily be around for another few years. Otherwise they'll find themselves doing the 3d effects for their regional weather channels talking about once whens."
