reviewText:
I held off writing this review until all the DLC came out because as is the case with many games nowadays community feedback and devoted developers often cause games to undergo big changes even after release, and this game is no exception. Many of the problems people had with the game when it came out are gone, and as a full package with all 4 DLC the game is fully realized and certainly worth your time and money.

This game is in a weird spot. If you're a shooter fan, it may feel like a fairly competent shooter, with some other weird turret things thrown in. If you're a Tower Defense player, it will feel very strange not always having a bird's eye veiw mainscreen (though there is a minimap and pressing a button will enlarge it so don't worry) and having these wierd variables of teammates and not having perfect aim all the time. If you like both, it is an outstanding blend of the two genres. And I recommend it to both fps and td fans. Fans of both sides may be dissapointed in the lack of this or that, but if you forget about games you've already played to compare it to for a minute, those things may not make sense in this hybrid.

That being said, the gameplay is phenomenal. A great blend of strategy and skill, but without requiring too many desicions and responsibilities that the player can easily become to overwhelmed. You build a maze, build towers (you choose what to bring beforehand) and then get to shooting. Mistakes are punished but don't mean the end until very late in the game. You have many ways to fix your holes and mistakes, even mid-wave. There is also an immense amount of freedom. Pro FPS-er? Take a bunch of perks that help you kill enemies and just let the towers clean up. TD Vet? Create a build that buffs your towers so you don't need to do much shooting. There's loads of combinations and styles of play that make the replay value even bigger. There's always that weird combo you want to try out for fun just to see if you can beat the level with it. The levels curve in very nicely, and there are enough modes and difficulty modifyers to keep you playing well after you've reached max level. Speaking of which, there's also a level up system where you unlock new weapons and perks. Early unlocks tend to be more general and easy to use, while still being powerful in their own right. Later unlocks are more specialized and require a bit more skill and familiarity with the game, and offer a slight better advantage if used correctly. No one unlock completely invalidates another, either. It's a very good system.

In addition, the single player and multiplayer are vastly different experiences. Play both. They're the exact same game but as soon as you have a team, its an almost completely different one. The way multiplayer and singleplayer seamlessly blend together is great as well, and usually only requires you to shift mindsets, not builds (at least in the middle of a map - organizing for the next one and specializing is one of the myriad ways the game becomes different).

The outstanding team at Coffeestain is one of the most hardworking and talented development teams I've seen from an indie studio in a long time. I often find myself drawing parallels between them and CDProjekt Red when they started out. You can see the level of attention to detail if you look at the game closely, how every little piece seems to sort of mesh together to make a very nice whole. The art and music direction is phenomenal, without saying anything and before the first wave even starts you get a feel for it, where you are, what you're doing, and the impact you're having. The comic book for loading screens just gives the right amount of context to understand what's going on, the environments, music, and enemies tell the real story.

The game isn't without its flaws though. Sometimes it can lag a little bit or disconnect you, but that could just be my bad internet. Many guns don't feel terribly satisfying to shoot because things don't have so much health, and many of the enemies look similar. It's hard to find to many criticisms for the game though.

Overall, I highly recommend you pick up the whole package. It isn't for everyone, I will concede, so I also recommend trying the demo and see how you like the first few levels. Then pick up the whole game and if you want to the season pass or individual DLCs. They're all fantastic additions to the game. One even includes a fifth playable character. Don't worry if your friends aren't getting it and you think you'll have no one to play with, the community here is also one of the friendliest I've ever encountered.

reviewText: It's basically Sanctum 1 that's been consolized.  No upgrading guns, you gotta level up in order to unlock more guns and gun slots (and same for towers and perks), there's only 15 max towers allowed per map, and there's sprinting and kickback from every weapon. Monsters are much more enjoyable and dynamic now, but the game itself is quite easy, the maps are not new in any way (though bosses punching their way through towers was fantastic), and the experience overall felt like a slow grind.  Would not recommend.  If you've played Sanctum 1 this game doesn't really have much to offer that's new.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Massive improvement over Sanctum 1. Leveling system doesn't feel grindy, and helps to introduce old and new sanctum players into the new towers and features. Multiplayer can be annoying sometimes with trolls public play, but overall the community is helpful and welcoming. Playing with friends is very rewarding and fun.

Let's start from the top. If it is not obvious already, Sanctum 2 is the sequel to Sanctum, the Unreal Engine-based game that came on the scene slow at first before it made a big breakout on Steam, prompting this sequel.

First impressions from a Sanctum 1 player: WOW, this game has fixed a lot of gameplay annoyances that the first Sanctum had. Sanctum 2 has trashed the high, inaccessible walls of its predecessor with more sensible barriers that the player can actually mantle. Also, towers can now be partially upgraded in between the proper levels" so no more sitting on 99 credits that can't do anything because you are one short of the upgrade. All of your towers maxed out? You can now OVERCHARGE them with excess money

Being low level also doesn't exclude you from playing with higher level players. Because each player is limited to a certain number of tower and perk slots
column18: you can always find a niche to fill in multiplayer (I enjoy playing the rocket launcher character and managing airborne minions).\n\nOverall
column19: I can't see a reason not to get this game if you enjoy Tower Defense or Action Shooters for that matter. Sanctum offers short
column20: replayable fun for a very low price. Buy this game!"

reviewText:
EDIT: While the below review still holds true for the most part, after having played the game more, I've come to the conclusion that Sanctum 2 has much more of a learning curve than Sanctum. Sanctum is pretty easy to just jump into and enjoy, while Sanctum 2 requires you to learn how to really play the game and get some specific upgrades before it starts being really good. However, once you get to that point, it is a great experience possibly even better than the first despite the shortcomings.

I give this a thumbs up overall because it is still a fun game; the blending of FPS and tower defense that is Sanctum is here, the maze-making strategy is here, and the multiplayer is better and more worthwhile than before. There are some good new features, but as a fan who loved and played a lot of the first, I am disappointed with a lot of the things they did here. But I'll start with the good:

Multiple characters to choose from adds a new element of strategy, and equipping appropriate perks adds further. As all bonuses that can theoretically stack together do, equipping each character with appropriate perks for the best results is a welcome addition to the franchise that allows players to experiment for the combos that best suit them.

Maps are much better designed than in the first Sanctum with much more attention to detail and more thought in strategic use of the environment. The campaign and leveling system are also a welcome addition, giving a feeling of progress, though some unlocks may take a bit too long to unlock. Lastly, there's a wider range of guns and towers available to choose from.

It also looks really nice graphically.

But now, the disappointments. I know this is a new game and shouldn't just be compared to the first, but as this is a sequel, things should get better, not worse, and a comparison will be necessary to make my point.

Most of my issues can be summed up as such: the maps may be bigger, but the game feels so much smaller. Customization was supposed to be an important upgrade from Sanctum to Sanctum 2, but I honestly feel like the first had better customization. Number of guns allowed to each player has been reduced from 3 to 2, with 1 of those being locked to the character until capping your level, meaning only one weapon can actually be chosen for any given character, AND they can no longer be upgraded. Yet despite this, the game is actually more FPS-centric due to the limits on blocks and towers, as even without any feats of strength activated one can't really get away with just towers, again unlike the first, making for fewer different ways to actually play the game.

Number of towers brought to a map maxes out at 4 per player, down from the 6 of the original. Additionally, floors are gone completely and Holo tower and Televators have also left the building, leaving basically only the two slowing towers to support the FPS aspect at all, and no guns which do the reverse (Freeze is gone), severing that integration completely aside from a few perks. Also, towers can only be upgraded to level 3 instead of 6, after which they go into overcharge
date:
which is just throwing as many extra resources as you want at it to make it more continually more powerful, and I guess is basically the same thing.

Blocks - now tower bases - are limited and given out per wave instead of costing a small amount of resources, preventing players from really building a maze until the map is over, seeing as maps are not longer than 10 waves, which was the shortest in the previous game, where it went as high as 30 in standard mode. Additionally, only 15 towers can actually be built per map, and the base cost of them has increased as much as 10x, no exaggeration; base Gatling now costs 100 instead of 10, and resources given hasn't increased to compensate (if anything it's lower). I guess as compensation upgrade costs don't increase as you continue to upgrade, but it doesn't matter much since they only go to level 3 and then overcharge anyway.

What's the point of the maps being so big if I can only realistically use small portions of them?

Good multiplayer is definitely not a bad thing in my book, but the game kind of shafts solo players. Many maps have multiple entry points for the enemies, occasionally in ways that prevent the two sides from ever joining before the core (and some have two cores), requiring a solo player to juggle two sides, a problem compounded further by the limitations to blocks and towers. A few of these maps existing would be fine, but not as many as there are here, especially since televators are no longer around to allow the player to move around quickly.

The game is definitely a better multiplayer experience than single. It can be played single player, but it will be frustrating at times. Best to get a friend or two in on the action. Again, still a good game overall. If you liked Sanctum but thought it needed some improving, this might be for you. If you liked a lot of things in Sanctum, give it a shot, but be careful.

reviewText:
This is NOT Sanctum 1. If you are going into this expecting it to be exactly like the first, then be forewarned that it is not. Also, in this review, I am including all DLC in my considerations, and I am including into consideration what this game has set out to be rather than what I personally expect from a TD or FPS game.

That having been said to appease the die hard purists of the original and the two genres, this game is on it's own merrit absolutely awesome. It has it's highs and lows like most any game, although there are a lot more highs than there are lows. There is a little bit of pacing and balance issues when it comes to playing straight through as you will inevitably hit a point where you are forced to improve not only your skill but also your choice of armaments or when certain armaments or combinations that are just completely overkill for the level you are facing. With sufficient skill and sufficient experience with the different combos, there is no reason you can't make almost any combination work, but getting to that skill point will take a bit of time and some trial and error that you just wont nail down on your first play through or until you've played enough to cap out you levels. On the higher difficulty levels though, that skill and knowing the combinations is critical and on the hardest difficulty for the most part you will need to bring your A game and the best combos you can muster. That is all part of what makes a good TD game though; possibilities and choices in how you play, replayability without getting stale fast, and the flexibility of different difficulties that includes something for the casual to the hardcore.

The FPS element does feel light, and the TD element does feel somewhat simplified when compared to their pure counterparts, but the state of both is perfect for the sake of trying to play both at once without getting overwhelmed as a new player and in order to prevent requiring days of number crunching or rote memorization of patterns. At some point though, you will beat everything and then it will boil down to just survival mode and how many waves can you kill before it's impossible. When you get to that point after playing for many many hours, it will inevitably get pretty dull for most.

All in all, just considering Sanctum 2 and only the scope of the game, I would give it a 80/85 in terms of what it set out to do and how well it delivers (points docked due to lack of really long term replayability for completionists, and minor pacing/balance issues). I would give it a 80/100 when comparing it against all other games I've ever played of all genres.

reviewText: Sanctum 2 is an excellent game, and in my own opinion, better than the first, a rarity in the gaming industry. Players of the original Sanctum will find that it has a similar feel to the original, but the small things take a lot of getting used to, for example the UI is packed with more information than before on a different location of the screen. Initially because of this, I found the game difficult to play, but after playing a few levels the interface was fairly easy to read from and playing was comfortable. The levels themselves are colossal, full of secrets, and both graphically and aesthetically pleasing. The game is well optimised, as shown by my less-than-stellar PC being able to handle this game fairly well with some graphical options turned off. The gameplay feels like a less-flamboyant Borderlands, which suits the aesthetic of the game well. The game does have it's bugs. I, on more than one occasion have found myself wedged between two slanted sections of wall and getting stuck. The game does have a suicide button for this purpose, but during a wave it can be irritating dealing with the 10-second respawn time as the enemy skips merrily towards the core. I have encountered crash bugs, although I suspect they're my PC's fault.\nI heartily reccomend Sanctum 2, and by extension, it's predecessor Sanctum. Sanctum 2 is certainly one of my top-5 games of all time and you should certainly buy it if you think it'd be your thing.

reviewText:
Overview: What a magnificent game.

So I ended up playing this for about 90 hours in total. What makes this game really special is how it challenges you to think and to improve your strategy as you're presented with newer levels and higher difficulties.

Sanctum 2 has 32 unique maps, and to win these at the hardest setting, you will need to select particular sets of weapons, towers, and perks. You need different combinations because some maps will be more suitable for relying on your towers, while others maximize your own attacks.

You can play through all the maps solo, or you can join in 4-player co-op. Co-op is tricky, because unless you know another player well, you might end up with some weird people joining your game from basic matchmaking. Since resources are shared, you wouldn't want to waste your limited resources.

Graphics: looks good. Use in conjunction with SweetFX to brighten some colours and remove noise.
Music: pretty fitting, with relaxing music during building phases, and faster tempos for fighting.

Overall: Very fun.

reviewText: Sanctum 2 is an excellent game, and in my own opinion, better than the first, a rarity in the gaming industry. Players of the original Sanctum will find that it has a similar feel to the original, but the small things take a lot of getting used to, for example the UI is packed with more information than before on a different location of the screen. Initially because of this, I found the game difficult to play, but after playing a few levels the interface was fairly easy to read from and playing was comfortable. The levels themselves are colossal, full of secrets, and both graphically and aesthetically pleasing. The game is well optimised, as shown by my less-than-stellar PC being able to handle this game fairly well with some graphical options turned off. The gameplay feels like a less-flamboyant Borderlands, which suits the aesthetic of the game well. The game does have it's bugs. I, on more than one occasion have found myself wedged between two slanted sections of wall and getting stuck. The game does have a suicide button for this purpose, but during a wave it can be irritating dealing with the 10-second respawn time as the enemy skips merrily towards the core. I have encountered crash bugs, although I suspect they're my PC's fault.\nI heartily reccomend Sanctum 2, and by extension, it's predecessor Sanctum. Sanctum 2 is certainly one of my top-5 games of all time and you should certainly buy it if you think it'd be your thing.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Overview: What a magnificent game.

So I ended up playing this for about 90 hours in total. What makes this game really special is how it challenges you to think and to improve your strategy as you're presented with newer levels and higher difficulties.

Sanctum 2 has 32 unique maps, and to win these at the hardest setting, you will need to select particular sets of weapons, towers, and perks. You need different combinations because some maps will be more suitable for relying on your towers, while others maximize your own attacks.

You can play through all the maps solo, or you can join in 4-player co-op. Co-op is tricky, because unless you know another player well, you might end up with some weird people joining your game from basic matchmaking. Since resources are shared, you wouldn't want to waste your limited resources.

Graphics: looks good. Use in conjunction with SweetFX to brighten some colours and remove noise.
Music: pretty fitting, with relaxing music during building phases, and faster tempos for fighting.

Overall: Very fun.

Rating: 10/10.

reviewText:
Coffee Stain Studios developed Sanctum 2 hits all the right spots and is clearly their best game yet. This is a sequel to Sanctum which was a pretty unique First-Person-Shooter/Tower Defence hybrid. While the first game had more feel of a 3D Tower Defence with a small help from you in the shooting part, Sanctum 2 throws the balance to more towards players - shooting and co-operation are very important if you are meaning to survive the large waves of enemies, yet leaving the building phase as a crucial stage too. The pacing of this game is very nice wave of fresh air as the shooting is balanced with the strategic planning of tower building.

Sanctum 2 improves the graphics (visual style is excellent in this game and gives it an unique vibe), gunplay and other gameplay mechanics vastly from the first one. Though, the first game has it own strengths so it's worth a check too, especially if you're interested more for the tower defence parts. But most importantly: buy Sanctum 2, it's one of the most exciting titles of 2013.

Be aware that the core of Sanctum 2 is the co-op experience so while it can be played alone, it's recommend with other people online.

reviewText:
RECOMMENDED, BUT WITH SOME CAVEATS. Overall, Sanctum 2 is better than the original. With the original Sanctum, the waves of invading monsters on the maps were too numerous (we're talking 15-30 waves per map!), which made each map increasingly monotonous and tiresome toward its end. What's worse, actual boredom started to creep into the game after beating the 2nd or 3rd map, because by then you had seen and done pretty much all there was in the game. Which made the subsequent maps, and especially the DLC, seem superfluous.

Sanctum 2 rectifies all that by 1.) greatly reducing the number of monster waves on each map (down to 6-12 waves); 2.) including boss monsters in the waves; 3.) making the monsters agressively seek you out and attack you, which can kill you (but you can respawn);  4.) grouping the maps into themed subdivisions; 5.) unlocking more and more towers as you progress through the game; 6.) offering four different characters to play, each with a special weapon and ability; 7.) unlocking more and more buffs and abilities as you progress through the game, which can be slotted in and out for each character, customizing them and the towers they work with.

However, the first-person shooter aspects of Sanctum continue to be flawed, perhaps even more so in Sanctum 2 than in the original. In either game, jumping is spongy and imprecise, and you tend to get tunnel-vision and disoriented in the mazes you create. What's worse in Sanctum 2, the point-of-view is ridiculously low to the ground, as if none of the characters have legs!  Also, you tend to get snagged by and stuck on the many fixtures and decorations of a map as you're running around, fighting the monsters. Like, on one map that really annoyed me, I kept getting snagged by the guard rails as I moved near them (oh, and the waist-high rails would obstruct me if I stopped and tried to lean over them, to shoot at the monsters below), and at one intersection on that map, there was a staple-like object on the floor that I kept getting stuck on as I ran over it.

Even so, I still recommend the Sanctum games, particularly the 2nd one. Especially if, like me, you enjoy and are challenged by tower-defense hybrid games.

reviewText:
EDIT: While the below review still holds true for the most part, after having played the game more, I've come to the conclusion that Sanctum 2 has much more of a learning curve than Sanctum. Sanctum is pretty easy to just jump into and enjoy, while Sanctum 2 requires you to learn how to really play the game and get some specific upgrades before it starts being really good. However, once you get to that point, it is a great experience possibly even better than the first despite the shortcomings.

I give this a thumbs up overall because it is still a fun game; the blending of FPS and tower defense that is Sanctum is here, the maze-making strategy is here, and the multiplayer is better and more worthwhile than before. There are some good new features, but as a fan who loved and played a lot of the first, I am disappointed with a lot of the things they did here. But I'll start with the good:

Multiple characters to choose from adds a new element of strategy, and equipping appropriate perks adds further. As all bonuses that can theoretically stack together do, equipping each character with appropriate perks for the best results is a welcome addition to the franchise that allows players to experiment for the combos that best suit them.

Maps are much better designed than in the first Sanctum with much more attention to detail and more thought in strategic use of the environment. The campaign and leveling system are also a welcome addition, giving a feeling of progress, though some unlocks may take a bit too long to unlock. Lastly, there's a wider range of guns and towers available to choose from.

It also looks really nice graphically.

But now, the disappointments. I know this is a new game and shouldn't just be compared to the first, but as this is a sequel, things should get better, not worse, and a comparison will be necessary to make my point.

Most of my issues can be summed up as such: the maps may be bigger, but the game feels so much smaller. Customization was supposed to be an important upgrade from Sanctum to Sanctum 2, but I honestly feel like the first had better customization. Number of guns allowed to each player has been reduced from 3 to 2, with 1 of those being locked to the character until capping your level, meaning only one weapon can actually be chosen for any given character, AND they can no longer be upgraded. Yet despite this, the game is actually more FPS-centric due to the limits on blocks and towers, as even without any feats of strength activated one can't really get away with just towers, again unlike the first, making for fewer different ways to actually play the game.

Number of towers brought to a map maxes out at 4 per player, down from the 6 of the original. Additionally, floors are gone completely and Holo tower and Televators have also left the building, leaving basically only the two slowing towers to support the FPS aspect at all, and no guns which do the reverse (Freeze is gone), severing that integration completely aside from a few perks. Also, towers can only be upgraded to level 3 instead of 6, after which they go into overcharge
date:
which is just throwing as many extra resources as you want at it to make it more continually more powerful, and I guess is basically the same thing.

Blocks - now tower bases - are limited and given out per wave instead of costing a small amount of resources, preventing players from really building a maze until the map is over, seeing as maps are not longer than 10 waves, which was the shortest in the previous game, where it went as high as 30 in standard mode. Additionally, only 15 towers can actually be built per map, and the base cost of them has increased as much as 10x, no exaggeration; base Gatling now costs 100 instead of 10, and resources given hasn't increased to compensate (if anything it's lower). I guess as compensation upgrade costs don't increase as you continue to upgrade, but it doesn't matter much since they only go to level 3 and then overcharge anyway.

What's the point of the maps being so big if I can only realistically use small portions of them?

Good multiplayer is definitely not a bad thing in my book, but the game kind of shafts solo players. Many maps have multiple entry points for the enemies, occasionally in ways that prevent the two sides from ever joining before the core (and some have two cores), requiring a solo player to juggle two sides, a problem compounded further by the limitations to blocks and towers. A few of these maps existing would be fine, but not as many as there are here, especially since televators are no longer around to allow the player to move around quickly.

The game is definitely a better multiplayer experience than single. It can be played single player, but it will be frustrating at times. Best to get a friend or two in on the action. Again, still a good game overall. If you liked Sanctum but thought it needed some improving, this might be for you. If you liked a lot of things in Sanctum, give it a shot, but be careful.

reviewText: The classical Tower Defense game remastered. A great way to have a ton of fun with your friends, it gets repetetive some hundreds of hours into the game I suppose because I have not found it so a single time. If you add one friend it gets twice as fun. If you add another you might as well be playing Super Mario on your old N64. It's that much fun. If this ever goes on sale it's a definite must, otherwise I recommend this if you're looking for an active group oriented Tower Defense that is more than just a TD Game.

reviewText: Tower defense, first person shooter action, aliens, robots, futuristic settings - what's not to love about Sanctum 2. Whether you've played the original or are a newcomer to the series, Sanctum 2 is an amazing game to play. There's not much to say but 'wow' when you realise how unique this game is - I don't think that I've personally seen any first person shooter/tower defense crosses before, but it's something that there needs to be more of, because the combination of strategy and action in this style of game leaves you having a LOT of fun if you're into those kind of games.

reviewText:
Coffee Stain Studios developed Sanctum 2 hits all the right spots and is clearly their best game yet. This is a sequel to Sanctum which was a pretty unique First-Person-Shooter/Tower Defence hybrid. While the first game had more feel of a 3D Tower Defence with a small help from you in the shooting part, Sanctum 2 throws the balance to more towards players - shooting and co-operation are very important if you are meaning to survive the large waves of enemies, yet leaving the building phase as a crucial stage too. The pacing of this game is very nice wave of fresh air as the shooting is balanced with the strategic planning of tower building.

Sanctum 2 improves the graphics (visual style is excellent in this game and gives it an unique vibe), gunplay and other gameplay mechanics vastly from the first one. Though, the first game has it own strengths so it's worth a check too, especially if you're interested more for the tower defence parts. But most importantly: buy Sanctum 2, it's one of the most exciting titles of 2013.

Be aware that the core of Sanctum 2 is the co-op experience so while it can be played alone, it's recommend with other people online.
